title: Buf Studio's People-First Approach Drives Growth (Sponsored Content)
text:
YOUR BUSINESS AUTHORITY
Springfield, MO
In a tight labor market where businesses struggle to find and retain qualified talent, local architectural firm Buf Studio has discovered that intentional culture development has become a primary competitive advantage. Founded in 2020, Buf Studio has built its growth strategy around creating an environment where people genuinely want to work.
For Managing Principal Ryan Faust, culture isn’t something that happens accidentally.
His intentional approach addresses a fundamental challenge many growing companies face. “I think most people get into their careers and they naturally want to grow,” Faust notes. “In order to retain the best, the company’s got to provide that opportunity for them.”
Brie Madden, Director of Business Development, sees the results firsthand. “Our principals do a really good job of instilling ownership. They create so many opportunities for you to learn and grow, that if you’re doing the same thing a year from now, that’s not because there wasn’t an opportunity.”
The firm’s approach centers on what Faust calls “mentorship over management.” Rather than traditional top-down control, Buf Studio empowers employees to drive projects while providing guidance from behind. “I tell people, look, obviously we have to manage our projects, but as a leader I’m going to mentor you,” Faust says.
This philosophy creates measurable business benefits. “Our 24-year-old designer feels ownership over their own project, Madden explains. They’re not just somebody in the background drafting something and they’re nameless and faceless.”
The impact extends directly to client relationships. “In the architecture field, we’re with our clients for so long. A normal project has about a two-year minimum,” Faust explains. “If you come into that project and you’re not positive, you’re not engaged, you’re not excited about the project, that’s a big problem because you’re not building a whole lot of trust with that client.”
While many companies struggle with remote work demands and work-life balance expectations, Buf Studio takes a different approach. They’ve chosen to require in-office presence while creating an environment that makes people want to be there. “We’re expected to be in the office, but we offset that with a lot of really great team building experiences that make people want to be in the office rather than working on their couch at home,” Madden notes.
One example is their weekly “Moment of Analog” (MOA). “On Wednesdays at 3:00 PM we do a moment of analog,” Faust describes. “The idea is to disconnect from your computer for 15 or 20 minutes. We’ll huddle up and just do something fun for a second. Last week it was like if you had a baby buffalo, what would you name it?”
This approach challenges conventional wisdom about flexibility. “I think it’s very easy to conflate the idea of work-life balance or a lot of flexibility or remote work with excellence,” Faust observes. “My question back to them is, well, tell me how that helps you be great at what you’re going to do.”
The firm’s success depends heavily on thoughtful recruitment. “You’ve really hired culture,” Faust emphasizes. “You can say whatever you want. ‘We’re this kind of firm, or that,’ but you’re not that kind of firm if you don’t hire those kinds of people.” The hiring process includes multiple interviews and personality assessments, Faust explains. “We use that to kind of analyze them and understand who they are a little bit better as a person.”
The underlying goal, however, is not to recruit for uniformity of thought. “We like people that think differently, that push us to think differently,” Madden clarifies. “What we do look for though, is uniformity in work ethic, because you’re not coming to Buf not to work. Period.”
For business leaders in any industry, Buf Studio’s approach offers practical insights. Culture development requires intentional effort, clear values, and consistent reinforcement. As Madden puts it, “Ryan includes us every quarter. He updates us exactly on what he’s thinking and dreaming and planning. He takes us along for the ride and it builds investment from all of us.”
In a competitive talent market, the companies that will thrive are those that don’t just offer jobs, but those who create environments where people can build meaningful careers. For Buf Studio, that philosophy isn’t just changing the workplace. It’s driving their growth.
